page.title: 03ARABLE FARMING (1),KIRKCALDY
page.content: Arable farming is the main commercial activity in this part of Fife. There are eighteen farms but these are not all worked independently, eg., Longloch and Glassmount are worked together(560 acres), as are Banchory and Craigencalt(686 acres), although the emphasis in each is quite different. By far the most abundant crop is {barley,}followed by{sown grass, wheat, {potatoes,}and small amounts of{peas,} {turips}and{oilseed rape. The more traditional methods of arable farming by crop rotation have been replaced by intensive cultivation in which successive crops of barley are grown in the same fields, by using modern chemical fertilisers and pesticides. All of the barley grown locally is taken to Kirkcaldy for malting in the preparation of whisky.
